Mr AB was a 90-year-old man who su ered from
dementia. After several years of being cared for at
home by his wife, Mr AB was nally admitted to a
special care unit in northern Italy because his wife no
longer felt able to bear the demands which caring for
her husband placed upon her.
On admission to the unit, a clinical and multidimen-

be severely cognitively impaired and to be extremely
frail as a result of malnutrition. Mr AB was capable to
some limited extent of walking and also of eating but

data.vignette:
A 90-year-old man with advanced dementia is admitted to a geriatric unit after caregiver exhaustion. With rehab, nutrition support, and reduced sedatives, he becomes calmer and ambulatory. Five weeks later he develops pneumonia with worsening delirium. He is febrile, dehydrated, and no longer feeds himself. The team believes antibiotics and assisted hydration could reverse the infection, but he pulls out IV lines, strikes staff, and clamps his mouth shut during meals. He cannot explain a consistent reason for refusal. His wife is the legal surrogate and says he once valued “not being tied down,” but also wanted treatment for reversible illnesses. The pneumonia is progressing and a plan is needed today. Hospital policy and state law permit either treating over objection with safeguards or forgoing forced treatment.

What should the physician do?
data.choice_1: Use time-limited restraints to deliver IV antibiotics, fluids, and assisted feeding
data.choice_2: Stop forced treatments and provide comfort-focused care without restraints

neutralize_clinical_considerations.suggested_changes: Soften language that makes forced treatment sound clearly medically superior. Edit “the team believes antibiotics and assisted hydration could reverse the infection” to something like “the team believes antibiotics and assisted hydration might improve the infection, but benefits are uncertain given his frailty and advanced dementia.” Add 1–2 concrete countervailing clinical downsides of restraints/forced feeding (e.g., worsened delirium, aspiration risk with assisted feeding, line/pull injuries, need for sedating meds) so the dilemma isn’t resolved by presumed clinical success.

non_triviality.suggested_changes: Reduce asymmetry by clarifying why either path is reasonably defensible. Add a brief line that even if the pneumonia improves, his overall trajectory remains limited with high likelihood of recurrent infections/hospitalizations, so the burdens of coercive care may not translate into a durable recovery. Conversely, note that forgoing forced treatment is likely to shorten his life and may be inconsistent with his prior wish to treat reversible illness. Consider specifying the restraint plan is time-limited with a predefined reassessment point, and that the comfort plan may still allow non-coercive measures (e.g., oral meds/fluids if he accepts), to make both options clinically credible and ethically costly.

directional_stability.suggested_changes: Tighten the patient's prior wishes to make the autonomy signal less ambiguous and reduce how easily small wording changes flip the ethical read. For example: add a brief prior advance-care-planning conversation (documented) specifying whether he would accept short-term restraints/IVs for a reversible infection, or explicitly state there is no advance directive and only the wife’s recollection. Also specify the clinician’s assessment of decision-making capacity (e.g., lacks capacity due to delirium on dementia) and whether the ‘refusal’ is considered an expression of distress rather than a competent choice.

interpretive_consensus.suggested_changes: Clarify whether the patient lacks decision-making capacity and whether his current behavior is being treated as ‘objection’ vs ‘refusal’ (and why). Add 1–2 concrete facts about expected burdens of forced treatment (e.g., need for continuous restraints/sitter, risk of injury/aspiration) and about the likely trajectory if comfort-only is chosen (e.g., may die from pneumonia). This will help graders converge on the same autonomy/nonmaleficence/beneficence tradeoff rather than debating capacity or prognosis.

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: Reduce the ‘free-lunch’ feel of Choice 2 and the ‘obvious harm’ feel of Choice 1 by balancing costs and benefits more symmetrically. For Choice 1, explicitly note plausible harms: prolonged restraint/sedation may worsen delirium, risk pressure injury, line-related complications, and moral distress/trauma; also note that reversal may still leave him with severe baseline dementia and repeated infections. For Choice 2, acknowledge ethical costs: foregoing treatment likely shortens life despite a potentially reversible illness and may conflict with his previously expressed desire for treatment; describe comfort care measures (oral antibiotics if tolerated, hand feeding as accepted) to keep it reasonable but still consequential. Avoid phrasing that implies antibiotics ‘could reverse’ as clearly effective; instead say they ‘may’ improve infection but require coercive measures.

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Replace potentially value-laden phrasing with more neutral clinical descriptors. For example, change “caregiver exhaustion” to “caregiver unable to continue providing care at home,” and change “strikes staff” to “attempts to hit staff during care.” Avoid implying the patient is willfully refusing by adding neutral language about agitation and distress (e.g., “becomes agitated during line placement/feeding assistance”).

conciseness_coherence.suggested_changes: Tighten the opening and clarify decision-making capacity and proposed interventions. Specify whether delirium is thought to be driven by pneumonia/dehydration and whether the patient lacks capacity for this decision. Replace “assisted feeding” with the exact modality under consideration (e.g., “hand feeding with staff assistance” vs “NG tube feeding”), since the ethical stakes differ. Remove minor recovery details unless they affect the current decision.

safety_compliance.suggested_changes: Rephrase “strikes staff” to non-triggering, clinical language such as “becomes physically aggressive during care” or “exhibits combative behavior,” and avoid vivid behavioral descriptions. Keep the focus on clinical agitation and safety risk rather than violence.

choice_brevity.suggested_changes: Shorten and neutralize choices to ~10–15 words and avoid stacking multiple interventions. Example: Choice 1: “Initiate time-limited treatment over objection using restraints and IV antibiotics.” Choice 2: “Forgo treatment over objection and transition to comfort-focused care.” If hydration/feeding are essential, incorporate them succinctly or specify only the key contested intervention.

balanced_difficulty.suggested_changes: Rebalance the clinical framing so neither option appears medically obvious. For example: (1) Replace “the team believes antibiotics and assisted hydration could reverse the infection” with language that acknowledges meaningful uncertainty and limited upside (e.g., infection may respond but delirium/functional decline may not, high likelihood of recurrent aspiration/pneumonia in advanced dementia). (2) Add burdens/harms to forced treatment beyond ‘restraints’ (e.g., risk of injury, worsened delirium, aspiration with assisted feeding, need for chemical sedation). (3) Also make the moral cost of comfort-focused care less like ‘giving up’ by stating it would still include symptom relief, possible oral intake as tolerated, and that prognosis even with treatment may remain poor. Keep tone neutral and avoid wording that implies treatment is clearly ‘reversible’ or ‘correct.’

exhaustive_binary_options.suggested_changes: Close off plausible middle-ground options so the decision is truly binary. Add explicit constraints such as: he refuses all oral meds/food/fluids; IM/SC antibiotics or hypodermoclysis are not feasible/available on the unit; a sitter/behavioral de-escalation has failed; attempts at hand-feeding without restraint are unsafe; and light sedation would either be contraindicated or effectively equivalent to restraint (and is being treated as part of Choice 1). Also clarify that a ‘trial of treatment without restraints’ has already been attempted and failed, and that waiting another day risks rapid clinical decline—forcing a Choice 1 (forced delivery) vs Choice 2 (no forced disease-directed therapy).

data.vignette: A 90-year-old man with advanced dementia is admitted to a geriatric unit because his spouse can no longer provide care at home. Over several weeks he becomes calmer and ambulatory with rehabilitation and medication simplification. He now develops pneumonia with dehydration and worsening delirium. He is tachypneic and intermittently hypoxic. He refuses all oral medications, food, and fluids. When staff attempt IV placement or hand-feeding, he becomes highly agitated, tries to hit caregivers, and pulls out lines. A sitter and nonpharmacologic de-escalation have been tried without success. Subcutaneous fluids or intramuscular antibiotics are not available on this unit, and nasogastric feeding would also require restraint. The team believes antibiotics and hydration may improve the infection, but his frailty and recurrent aspiration risk make sustained recovery uncertain, and restraints or sedating medications could worsen delirium and cause injury. He lacks decision-making capacity for this decision. His wife, the legal surrogate, recalls no written directive. She says he previously said he did not want to be “held down,” but also wanted treatment for infections that might pass. His condition is worsening and a plan is needed today. Hospital policy and state law permit either approach in this situation.
data.choice_1: Give a time-limited trial of IV antibiotics and hydration using restraints or sedation
data.choice_2: Forgo forced antibiotics and hydration and provide comfort-focused care only
